sn22.53:1.2.eng: “Mendicants, if you get involved, you’re not free. If you’re not involved, you’re free.

sn22.53:1.3.pli: Rūpupayaṃ vā, bhikkhave, viññāṇaṃ tiṭṭhamānaṃ tiṭṭheyya, rūpārammaṇaṃ rūpappatiṭṭhaṃ nandūpasecanaṃ vuddhiṃ virūḷhiṃ vepullaṃ āpajjeyya.
sn22.53:1.3.eng: As long as consciousness continues, it would get involved with form, supported by form, established on form. And with a sprinkle of relishing, it would grow, increase, and mature.
sn22.53:1.3.comm: This is the consciousness that “continues” in transmigration (DN 33:1.11.122, SN 22.54:1.11, SN 12.38–40). It is described in organic terms, as something that grows like a plant.

sn22.53:1.4.eng: Or consciousness would get involved with feeling …

sn22.53:1.5.eng: Or consciousness would get involved with perception …

sn22.53:1.6.pli: saṅkhārupayaṃ vā, bhikkhave, viññāṇaṃ tiṭṭhamānaṃ tiṭṭheyya, saṅkhārārammaṇaṃ saṅkhārappatiṭṭhaṃ nandūpasecanaṃ vuddhiṃ virūḷhiṃ vepullaṃ āpajjeyya.
sn22.53:1.6.eng: Or as long as consciousness continues, it would get involved with choices, supported by choices, established on choices. And with a sprinkle of relishing, it would grow, increase, and mature.

sn22.53:2.2.pli: ‘ahamaññatra rūpā aññatra vedanāya aññatra saññāya aññatra saṅkhārehi viññāṇassa āgatiṃ vā gatiṃ vā cutiṃ vā upapattiṃ vā vuddhiṃ vā virūḷhiṃ vā vepullaṃ vā paññāpessāmī’ti, netaṃ ṭhānaṃ vijjati.
sn22.53:2.2.eng: ‘Apart from form, feeling, perception, and choices, I will describe the coming and going of consciousness, its passing away and reappearing, its growth, increase, and maturity.’ That is not possible.
sn22.53:2.2.comm: The process of rebirth is often described in terms of consciousness, as in dependent origination or, say, the “stream of consciousness” (DN 28:7.13). However, consciousness never exists by itself, but only in relation to the other aggregates. The case of the formless realm might seem an exception, yet even formless rebirth is dependent on form of the past, since the four “form” absorptions are the basis for the formless attainments. Thus while the formless realms can be described without reference to present form they cannot be described without reference to form at all.

sn22.53:3.1.pli: Rūpadhātuyā ce, bhikkhave, bhikkhuno rāgo pahīno hoti.
sn22.53:3.1.eng: If a mendicant has given up greed for the form element,

sn22.53:3.2.pli: Rāgassa pahānā vocchijjatārammaṇaṃ patiṭṭhā viññāṇassa na hoti.
sn22.53:3.2.eng: the support is cut off, and there is no establishment of consciousness.

sn22.53:3.3.eng: If a mendicant has given up greed for the feeling element …

sn22.53:3.6.pli: viññāṇadhātuyā ce, bhikkhave, bhikkhuno rāgo pahīno hoti.

sn22.53:3.7.pli: Rāgassa pahānā vocchijjatārammaṇaṃ patiṭṭhā viññāṇassa na hoti.
sn22.53:3.7.eng: the support is cut off, and there is no establishment of consciousness.

sn22.53:3.8.eng: Since that consciousness does not become established and does not grow, not making choices, it is freed.

sn22.53:3.9.pli: Vimuttattā ṭhitaṃ. Ṭhitattā santusitaṃ. Santusitattā na paritassati. Aparitassaṃ paccattaññeva parinibbāyati.
sn22.53:3.9.eng: Being free, it’s stable. Being stable, it’s content. Being content, they’re not anxious. Not being anxious, they personally become extinguished.
sn22.53:3.9.comm: In this passage, the pronouns have disappeared, in a syntactic mirroring of the vanishing of the delusion of self. Literally: “Because freed, stabilized. Because stabilized, contented. Because contented, is not anxious. Not being anxious, personally extinguish.”

sn22.53:3.10.pli: ‘Khīṇā jāti, vusitaṃ brahmacariyaṃ, kataṃ karaṇīyaṃ, nāparaṃ itthattāyā’ti pajānātī”ti.
sn22.53:3.10.eng: They understand: ‘Rebirth is ended, the spiritual journey has been completed, what had to be done has been done, there is nothing further for this place.’”

sn22.54:1.2.eng: “Mendicants, there are five kinds of plants.
sn22.54:1.2.comm: These terms are defined in detail in Bu Pc 11:2.1.1. Bījajāta are not “kinds of seeds” but “that which is born from a seed” i.e. “plants” (bhūtagāmo nāma pañca bījajātāni).

sn22.54:1.4.pli: Mūlabījaṃ, khandhabījaṃ, aggabījaṃ, phalubījaṃ, bījabījaññeva pañcamaṃ.
sn22.54:1.4.eng: Plants propagated from roots, stems, cuttings, or joints; and those from regular seeds are the fifth.
sn22.54:1.4.comm: “Plants propagated from roots” (mūlabīja, literally “that which has a root for a seed”) include ginger and turmeric; from “stems” (khandhabīja) the Bodhi tree and the banyan tree; from “cuttings” (aggabīja) basil and hemp; from “joints” (phalubīja) sugarcane and bamboo; and from “regular seeds” (bījabīja), grains and vegetables.

sn22.54:1.5.pli: Imāni cassu, bhikkhave, pañca bījajātāni akhaṇḍāni apūtikāni avātātapahatāni sārādāni sukhasayitāni, pathavī ca nāssa, āpo ca nāssa;
sn22.54:1.5.eng: Suppose these five kinds of plants were intact, unspoiled, not weather-damaged, fertile, and well-kept. But there’s no earth or water.
sn22.54:1.5.comm: Sukhasayita is sometimes understood as “well planted”, but how can it be planted when there is no soil? It is explained by the commentary as “well-kept”, literally “well laid by”.

sn22.54:1.6.pli: api numāni, bhikkhave, pañca bījajātāni vuddhiṃ virūḷhiṃ vepullaṃ āpajjeyyun”ti?
sn22.54:1.6.eng: Then would these five kinds of plants reach growth, increase, and maturity?”

sn22.54:1.8.pli: “Imāni cassu, bhikkhave, pañca bījajātāni akhaṇḍāni …pe… sukhasayitāni, pathavī ca assa, āpo ca assa;
sn22.54:1.8.eng: “Suppose these five kinds of plants were intact, unspoiled, not weather-damaged, fertile, and well-kept. And there is earth and water.

sn22.54:1.9.pli: api numāni, bhikkhave, pañca bījajātāni vuddhiṃ virūḷhiṃ vepullaṃ āpajjeyyun”ti?
sn22.54:1.9.eng: Then would these five kinds of plants reach growth, increase, and maturity?”

sn22.54:1.11.pli: “Seyyathāpi, bhikkhave, pathavīdhātu, evaṃ catasso viññāṇaṭṭhitiyo daṭṭhabbā.
sn22.54:1.11.eng: “The four grounds for consciousness should be seen as like the earth element.
sn22.54:1.11.comm: Pali uses the same word viññāṇaṭṭhiti for the seven “planes of consciousness” (realms of rebirth, AN 7.44, DN 15:33.1) as for the four “grounds for consciousness”, the other four aggregates on which consciousness is based.

sn22.54:1.12.pli: Seyyathāpi, bhikkhave, āpodhātu, evaṃ nandirāgo daṭṭhabbo.
sn22.54:1.12.eng: Relishing and greed should be seen as like the water element.

sn22.54:1.13.pli: Seyyathāpi, bhikkhave, pañca bījajātāni, evaṃ viññāṇaṃ sāhāraṃ daṭṭhabbaṃ.
sn22.54:1.13.eng: Consciousness with its fuel should be seen as like the five kinds of plants.
sn22.54:1.13.comm: See too AN 3.76:2.3: “deeds are the field, consciousness is the seed, and craving is the moisture”.

sn22.54:2.1.pli: Rūpupayaṃ, bhikkhave, viññāṇaṃ tiṭṭhamānaṃ tiṭṭheyya, rūpārammaṇaṃ rūpappatiṭṭhaṃ nandūpasecanaṃ vuddhiṃ virūḷhiṃ vepullaṃ āpajjeyya.
sn22.54:2.1.eng: As long as consciousness continues, it would get involved with form, supported by form, established on form. And with a sprinkle of relishing, it would grow, increase, and mature.

sn22.54:2.2.pli: Vedanupayaṃ vā, bhikkhave, viññāṇaṃ tiṭṭhamānaṃ tiṭṭheyya …pe…
sn22.54:2.2.eng: Or consciousness would get involved with feeling …

sn22.54:2.3.pli: saññupayaṃ vā, bhikkhave, viññāṇaṃ tiṭṭhamānaṃ tiṭṭheyya …pe…
sn22.54:2.3.eng: Or consciousness would get involved with perception …

sn22.54:2.4.pli: saṅkhārupayaṃ vā, bhikkhave, viññāṇaṃ tiṭṭhamānaṃ tiṭṭheyya, saṅkhārārammaṇaṃ saṅkhārappatiṭṭhaṃ nandūpasecanaṃ vuddhiṃ virūḷhiṃ vepullaṃ āpajjeyya.
sn22.54:2.4.eng: Or as long as consciousness continues, it would get involved with choices, supported by choices, established on choices. And with a sprinkle of relishing, it would grow, increase, and mature.

sn22.54:3.2.pli: ‘ahamaññatra rūpā aññatra vedanāya aññatra saññāya aññatra saṅkhārehi viññāṇassa āgatiṃ vā gatiṃ vā cutiṃ vā upapattiṃ vā vuddhiṃ vā virūḷhiṃ vā vepullaṃ vā paññāpessāmī’ti, netaṃ ṭhānaṃ vijjati.
sn22.54:3.2.eng: ‘Apart from form, feeling, perception, and choices, I will describe the coming and going of consciousness, its passing away and reappearing, its growth, increase, and maturity.’ That is not possible.

sn22.54:4.1.pli: Rūpadhātuyā ceva, bhikkhave, bhikkhuno rāgo pahīno hoti.
sn22.54:4.1.eng: If a mendicant has given up greed for the form element,

sn22.54:4.2.pli: Rāgassa pahānā vocchijjatārammaṇaṃ patiṭṭhā viññāṇassa na hoti.
sn22.54:4.2.eng: the support is cut off, and there is no establishment of consciousness.
sn22.54:4.2.comm: For the “establishment of consciousness”, namely the rebirth of consciousness in a new life, see too SN 12.64.

sn22.54:4.3.eng: If a mendicant has given up greed for the feeling element …

sn22.54:4.6.pli: viññāṇadhātuyā ce, bhikkhave, bhikkhuno rāgo pahīno hoti.

sn22.54:4.7.pli: Rāgassa pahānā vocchijjatārammaṇaṃ patiṭṭhā viññāṇassa na hoti.
sn22.54:4.7.eng: the support is cut off, and there is no establishment of consciousness.

sn22.54:4.8.eng: Since that consciousness does not become established and does not grow, not making choices, it is freed.

sn22.54:4.9.pli: Vimuttattā ṭhitaṃ. Ṭhitattā santusitaṃ. Santusitattā na paritassati. Aparitassaṃ paccattaññeva parinibbāyati.
sn22.54:4.9.eng: Being free, it’s stable. Being stable, it’s content. Being content, they’re not anxious. Not being anxious, they personally become extinguished.

sn22.54:4.10.eng: They understand: ‘Rebirth is ended … there is nothing further for this place.’”

sn22.55:1.2.eng: There the Buddha expressed this heartfelt sentiment:

sn22.55:1.3.pli: “‘no cassaṃ, no ca me siyā, nābhavissa, na me bhavissatī’ti—
sn22.55:1.3.eng: “‘It might not be, and it might not be mine. It will not be, and it will not be mine.’
sn22.55:1.3.comm: I follow the interpretation established by Bhikkhu Bodhi, for which see his note 75 on this discourse in Connected Discourses. When using first person pronouns, the formula epitomizes the annihilationist view: “I might not be” (SN 22.81:11.9, SN 24.4:1.3, SN 22.153:1.3, AN 10.29:19.1). The Buddha reformed it with the impersonal third person pronoun: “It might not be”.

sn22.55:1.4.pli: evaṃ adhimuccamāno bhikkhu chindeyya orambhāgiyāni saṃyojanānī”ti.
sn22.55:1.4.eng: A mendicant who makes such a resolution can cut off the lower fetters.”

sn22.55:1.5.pli: Evaṃ vutte, aññataro bhikkhu bhagavantaṃ etadavoca:
sn22.55:1.5.eng: When he said this, one of the mendicants asked the Buddha,

sn22.55:1.6.pli: “yathā kathaṃ pana, bhante, ‘no cassaṃ, no ca me siyā, nābhavissa, na me bhavissatī’ti—

sn22.55:1.7.pli: evaṃ adhimuccamāno bhikkhu chindeyya orambhāgiyāni saṃyojanānī”ti?
sn22.55:1.7.eng: can a mendicant who makes such a resolution cut off the lower fetters?”

sn22.55:2.1.eng: “Mendicant, take an unlearned ordinary person who has not seen the noble ones, and is neither skilled nor trained in their teaching. They’ve not seen true persons, and are neither skilled nor trained in their teaching.

sn22.55:2.2.pli: sappurisadhamme avinīto rūpaṃ attato samanupassati, rūpavantaṃ vā attānaṃ; attani vā rūpaṃ, rūpasmiṃ vā attānaṃ.
sn22.55:2.2.eng: They regard form as self, self as having form, form in self, or self in form.

sn22.55:2.6.pli: viññāṇaṃ attato samanupassati, viññāṇavantaṃ vā attānaṃ; attani vā viññāṇaṃ, viññāṇasmiṃ vā attānaṃ.
sn22.55:2.6.eng: consciousness as self, self as having consciousness, consciousness in self, or self in consciousness.

sn22.55:3.1.pli: So aniccaṃ rūpaṃ ‘aniccaṃ rūpan’ti yathābhūtaṃ nappajānāti,
sn22.55:3.1.eng: They don’t truly understand form—which is impermanent—as impermanent.

sn22.55:4.1.eng: They don’t truly understand form—which is suffering—as suffering.

sn22.55:5.1.eng: They don’t truly understand form—which is not-self—as not-self.

sn22.55:6.1.eng: They don’t truly understand form—which is conditioned—as conditioned.

sn22.55:6.6.eng: They don’t truly understand that form will vanish.

sn22.55:6.7.eng: They don’t truly understand that feeling …

sn22.55:7.1.pli: Sutavā ca kho, bhikkhu, ariyasāvako ariyānaṃ dassāvī ariyadhammassa kovido ariyadhamme suvinīto sappurisānaṃ dassāvī sappurisadhammassa kovido sappurisadhamme suvinīto
sn22.55:7.1.eng: But a learned noble disciple has seen the noble ones, and is skilled and trained in the teaching of the noble ones. They’ve seen true persons, and are skilled and trained in the teaching of the true persons.

sn22.55:7.2.eng: They don’t regard form as self …

sn22.55:8.1.pli: So aniccaṃ rūpaṃ ‘aniccaṃ rūpan’ti yathābhūtaṃ pajānāti.
sn22.55:8.1.eng: They truly understand form—which is impermanent—as impermanent.

sn22.55:8.6.eng: They truly understand form … feeling … perception … choices … consciousness—which is suffering—as suffering.

sn22.55:8.7.eng: They truly understand form … feeling … perception … choices … consciousness—which is not-self—as not-self.

sn22.55:8.8.pli: saṅkhataṃ rūpaṃ …pe… saṅkhataṃ viññāṇaṃ ‘saṅkhataṃ viññāṇan’ti yathābhūtaṃ pajānāti.
sn22.55:8.8.eng: They truly understand form … feeling … perception … choices … consciousness—which is conditioned—as conditioned.

sn22.55:8.9.eng: They truly understand that form will vanish.
sn22.55:8.9.comm: “Will vanish” is vibhavissati, literally “will cease to be”, the verbal form of the word “nonexistence” (vibhava) in the second noble truth. It’s used throughout Snp 4.11 and, in a meditation context, in AN 11.9:7.1. At Iti 49:7.3 it refers to the ending of continued existence for an arahant.

sn22.55:9.1.pli: So rūpassa vibhavā, vedanāya vibhavā, saññāya vibhavā, saṅkhārānaṃ vibhavā, viññāṇassa vibhavā, evaṃ kho, bhikkhu,
sn22.55:9.1.eng: It’s because of the vanishing of form, feeling, perception, choices, and consciousness that a mendicant who makes such a resolution—

sn22.55:9.2.pli: ‘no cassaṃ, no ca me siyā, nābhavissa, na me bhavissatī’ti—
sn22.55:9.2.eng: ‘It might not be, and it might not be mine. It will not be, and it will not be mine’—

sn22.55:9.3.pli: evaṃ adhimuccamāno bhikkhu chindeyya orambhāgiyāni saṃyojanānī”ti.
sn22.55:9.3.eng: can cut off the lower fetters.”

sn22.55:9.4.eng: “Sir, you say that a mendicant who makes such a resolution can cut off the lower fetters.
sn22.55:9.4.comm: Here the monk quotes the Buddha, as indicated by the close -ti in the text.

sn22.55:10.1.pli: Kathaṃ pana, bhante, jānato kathaṃ passato anantarā āsavānaṃ khayo hotī”ti?
sn22.55:10.1.eng: But how are they to know and see in order to end the defilements without delay?”
sn22.55:10.1.comm: This question is also at SN 22.81:4.4.

sn22.55:10.2.pli: “Idha, bhikkhu, assutavā puthujjano atasitāye ṭhāne tāsaṃ āpajjati.
sn22.55:10.2.eng: “Mendicant, an unlearned ordinary person worries about things that aren’t a worry.

sn22.55:10.3.eng: For an unlearned ordinary person worries:

sn22.55:10.4.pli: ‘no cassaṃ, no ca me siyā, nābhavissa, na me bhavissatī’ti.
sn22.55:10.4.eng: ‘It might not be, and it might not be mine. It will not be, and it will not be mine.’

sn22.55:11.1.pli: Sutavā ca kho, bhikkhu, ariyasāvako atasitāye ṭhāne na tāsaṃ āpajjati.
sn22.55:11.1.eng: A learned noble disciple doesn’t worry about things that aren’t a worry.

sn22.55:11.2.pli: Na heso, bhikkhu, tāso sutavato ariyasāvakassa:
sn22.55:11.2.eng: For a learned noble disciple doesn’t worry:

sn22.55:11.3.pli: ‘no cassaṃ, no ca me siyā, nābhavissa, na me bhavissatī’ti.
sn22.55:11.3.eng: ‘It might not be, and it might not be mine. It will not be, and it will not be mine.’

sn22.55:11.4.pli: Rūpupayaṃ vā, bhikkhu, viññāṇaṃ tiṭṭhamānaṃ tiṭṭheyya, rūpārammaṇaṃ rūpappatiṭṭhaṃ nandūpasecanaṃ vuddhiṃ virūḷhiṃ vepullaṃ āpajjeyya.
sn22.55:11.4.eng: As long as consciousness continues, it would get involved with form, supported by form, established on form. And with a sprinkle of relishing, it would grow, increase, and mature.

sn22.55:11.5.eng: Or consciousness would get involved with feeling …

sn22.55:11.6.eng: Or consciousness would get involved with perception …

sn22.55:11.7.pli: saṅkhārupayaṃ vā, bhikkhu, viññāṇaṃ tiṭṭhamānaṃ tiṭṭheyya, saṅkhārārammaṇaṃ saṅkhārappatiṭṭhaṃ nandūpasecanaṃ vuddhiṃ virūḷhiṃ vepullaṃ āpajjeyya.
sn22.55:11.7.eng: Or consciousness would get involved with choices, supported by choices, grounded on choices. And with a sprinkle of relishing, it would grow, increase, and mature.

sn22.55:12.1.eng: Suppose, mendicant, you were to say:

sn22.55:12.2.pli: ‘ahamaññatra rūpā, aññatra vedanāya, aññatra saññāya, aññatra saṅkhārehi viññāṇassa āgatiṃ vā gatiṃ vā cutiṃ vā upapattiṃ vā vuddhiṃ vā virūḷhiṃ vā vepullaṃ vā paññāpessāmī’ti, netaṃ ṭhānaṃ vijjati.
sn22.55:12.2.eng: ‘Apart from form, feeling, perception, and choices, I will describe the coming and going of consciousness, its passing away and reappearing, its growth, increase, and maturity.’ That is not possible.

sn22.55:13.1.pli: Rūpadhātuyā ce, bhikkhu, bhikkhuno rāgo pahīno hoti. Rāgassa pahānā vocchijjatārammaṇaṃ patiṭṭhā viññāṇassa na hoti.
sn22.55:13.1.eng: If a mendicant has given up greed for the form element, the support is cut off, and there is no establishment of consciousness.

sn22.55:13.2.eng: If a mendicant has given up greed for the feeling element …

sn22.55:13.5.pli: viññāṇadhātuyā ce, bhikkhu, bhikkhuno rāgo pahīno hoti. Rāgassa pahānā vocchijjatārammaṇaṃ patiṭṭhā viññāṇassa na hoti.
sn22.55:13.5.eng: consciousness element, the support is cut off, and there is no establishment of consciousness.

sn22.55:13.6.eng: Since that consciousness does not become established and does not grow, not making choices, it is freed.

sn22.55:13.7.pli: Vimuttattā ṭhitaṃ. Ṭhitattā santusitaṃ. Santusitattā na paritassati. Aparitassaṃ paccattaññeva parinibbāyati.
sn22.55:13.7.eng: Being free, it’s stable. Being stable, it’s content. Being content, they’re not anxious. Not being anxious, they personally become extinguished.

sn22.55:13.8.eng: They understand: ‘Rebirth is ended … there is nothing further for this place.’

sn22.55:13.9.pli: Evaṃ kho, bhikkhu, jānato evaṃ passato anantarā āsavānaṃ khayo hotī”ti.
sn22.55:13.9.eng: The ending of the defilements is for one who knows and sees this.”

sn22.56:1.1.comm: The aggregates lack a formal “analysis” discourse. This discourse and the next, however, fill that gap by defining the aggregates. The definitions of form, feeling, and consciousness are shared with dependent origination (SN 12.2).

sn22.56:1.2.eng: “Mendicants, there are these five grasping aggregates.

sn22.56:1.4.eng: The grasping aggregates of form, feeling, perception, choices, and consciousness.

sn22.56:1.5.pli: Yāvakīvañcāhaṃ, bhikkhave, ime pañcupādānakkhandhe catuparivaṭṭaṃ yathābhūtaṃ nābbhaññāsiṃ, neva tāvāhaṃ, bhikkhave, sadevake loke samārake sabrahmake sassamaṇabrāhmaṇiyā pajāya sadevamanussāya anuttaraṃ sammāsambodhiṃ abhisambuddhoti paccaññāsiṃ.
sn22.56:1.5.eng: As long as I didn’t truly understand these five grasping aggregates in four rounds, I didn’t announce my supreme perfect awakening in this world with its gods, Māras, and Divinities, this population with its ascetics and brahmins, its gods and humans.
sn22.56:1.5.comm: Compare the “three rounds” of SN 56.11:9.1 and the “eight rounds” of AN 8.64:10.1.

sn22.56:1.6.pli: Yato ca khvāhaṃ, bhikkhave, ime pañcupādānakkhandhe catuparivaṭṭaṃ yathābhūtaṃ abbhaññāsiṃ, athāhaṃ, bhikkhave, sadevake loke …pe…
sn22.56:1.6.eng: But when I did truly understand these five grasping aggregates in four rounds, I announced my supreme perfect awakening in this world with its gods, Māras, and Divinities, this population with its ascetics and brahmins, its gods and humans.

sn22.56:2.1.eng: And how are there four rounds?

sn22.56:2.2.pli: Rūpaṃ abbhaññāsiṃ, rūpasamudayaṃ abbhaññāsiṃ, rūpanirodhaṃ abbhaññāsiṃ, rūpanirodhagāminiṃ paṭipadaṃ abbhaññāsiṃ;
sn22.56:2.2.eng: I directly knew form, its origin, its cessation, and the practice that leads to its cessation.

sn22.56:2.6.pli: viññāṇaṃ abbhaññāsiṃ, viññāṇasamudayaṃ abbhaññāsiṃ, viññāṇanirodhaṃ abbhaññāsiṃ, viññāṇanirodhagāminiṃ paṭipadaṃ abbhaññāsiṃ.
sn22.56:2.6.eng: consciousness, its origin, its cessation, and the practice that leads to its cessation.

sn22.56:3.2.pli: Cattāro ca mahābhūtā catunnañca mahābhūtānaṃ upādāya rūpaṃ.
sn22.56:3.2.eng: The four principal states, and form derived from the four principal states.
sn22.56:3.2.comm: The “principal states” (mahābhūtā) are earth, water, fire, and air, corresponding to the states of matter, namely solid, liquid, plasma, and gas. For the history of this term, see note on MN 28:4.2. | “Derived” (upādāya) form is not explained in the suttas, but one passage indicates it includes “space” (MN 28:26.1). The Abhidhamma traditions explain it as including the objects of the senses, the subtle matter that receives sense impressions, and various other material phenomena.

sn22.56:3.4.comm: For the topic of “fuel” (āhāra), here primarily meaning “food”, see  SN 12.11, SN 12.63, MN 9:10.2, SN 47.42.

sn22.56:3.6.pli: Ayameva ariyo aṭṭhaṅgiko maggo rūpanirodhagāminī paṭipadā, seyyathidaṃ—
sn22.56:3.6.eng: The practice that leads to the cessation of form is simply this noble eightfold path, that is:

sn22.56:3.7.eng: right view, right thought, right speech, right action, right livelihood, right effort, right mindfulness, and right immersion.

sn22.56:4.1.pli: Ye hi keci, bhikkhave, samaṇā vā brāhmaṇā vā evaṃ rūpaṃ abhiññāya, evaṃ rūpasamudayaṃ abhiññāya, evaṃ rūpanirodhaṃ abhiññāya, evaṃ rūpanirodhagāminiṃ paṭipadaṃ abhiññāya rūpassa nibbidāya virāgāya nirodhāya paṭipannā, te suppaṭipannā.
sn22.56:4.1.eng: Whatever ascetics and brahmins have directly known form in this way—and its origin, its cessation, and the practice that leads to its cessation—and are practicing for disillusionment, dispassion, and cessation regarding form: they are practicing well.

sn22.56:4.2.pli: Ye suppaṭipannā, te imasmiṃ dhammavinaye gādhanti.
sn22.56:4.2.eng: Those who practice well have a footing in this teaching and training.
sn22.56:4.2.comm: Those who “have a footing” (gādhanti) are the noble individuals who are trainees. A gādha is a “ford” across a river (Rig Veda 7.60.7, 7.97.8, 10.106.9; Gopatha Brāhmaṇa 1.5.2a), a safe path on which one has a “footing” to cross the water.

sn22.56:5.1.pli: Ye ca kho keci, bhikkhave, samaṇā vā brāhmaṇā vā evaṃ rūpaṃ abhiññāya …pe… evaṃ rūpanirodhagāminiṃ paṭipadaṃ abhiññāya, rūpassa nibbidā virāgā nirodhā anupādā vimuttā te suvimuttā.
sn22.56:5.1.eng: Those ascetics and brahmins who have directly known form in this way—and its origin, its cessation, and the practice that leads to its cessation—and due to disillusionment, dispassion, and cessation regarding form, are freed by not grasping: they are well freed.

sn22.56:5.2.eng: Those who are well freed are consummate ones.
sn22.56:5.2.comm: Kevala has the root meaning of “entire”, “exclusive”. For the Jains, kevalī came to mean “one whose knowledge is entire”, i.e. an omniscient one. The Buddha used it to indicate one who has consummated the entire path.

sn22.56:5.3.pli: Ye kevalino vaṭṭaṃ tesaṃ natthi paññāpanāya.
sn22.56:5.3.eng: For consummate ones, there is no cycle of rebirths to be found.

sn22.56:6.2.eng: There are these six classes of feeling:

sn22.56:6.3.pli: cakkhusamphassajā vedanā, sotasamphassajā vedanā, ghānasamphassajā vedanā, jivhāsamphassajā vedanā, kāyasamphassajā vedanā, manosamphassajā vedanā.
sn22.56:6.3.eng: feeling born of contact through the eye, ear, nose, tongue, body, and mind.

sn22.56:6.7.pli: Ayameva ariyo aṭṭhaṅgiko maggo vedanānirodhagāminī paṭipadā, seyyathidaṃ—
sn22.56:6.7.eng: The practice that leads to the cessation of feelings is simply this noble eightfold path …

sn22.56:7.1.pli: Ye hi keci, bhikkhave, samaṇā vā brāhmaṇā vā evaṃ vedanaṃ abhiññāya, evaṃ vedanāsamudayaṃ abhiññāya, evaṃ vedanānirodhaṃ abhiññāya, evaṃ vedanānirodhagāminiṃ paṭipadaṃ abhiññāya vedanāya nibbidāya virāgāya nirodhāya paṭipannā, te suppaṭipannā.

sn22.56:7.2.pli: Ye suppaṭipannā, te imasmiṃ dhammavinaye gādhanti.

sn22.56:8.1.pli: Ye ca kho keci, bhikkhave, samaṇā vā brāhmaṇā vā evaṃ vedanaṃ abhiññāya …pe… evaṃ vedanānirodhagāminiṃ paṭipadaṃ abhiññāya …pe…

sn22.56:9.2.eng: There are these six classes of perception:

sn22.56:9.3.pli: rūpasaññā, saddasaññā, gandhasaññā, rasasaññā, phoṭṭhabbasaññā, dhammasaññā.
sn22.56:9.3.eng: perceptions of sights, sounds, smells, tastes, touches, and ideas.

sn22.56:9.7.pli: Ayameva ariyo aṭṭhaṅgiko maggo saññānirodhagāminī paṭipadā, seyyathidaṃ—
sn22.56:9.7.eng: The practice that leads to the cessation of perceptions is simply this noble eightfold path …

sn22.56:10.1.comm: Here “choices” (saṅkhārā) are explicitly defined as “intentions” (sañcetanā), a meaning that is consistent in this context and reflected in the common idiom “choices and intentions” (eg. SN 12.37:1.3). See notes on SN 12.2:13.3 and SN 12.51:9.1. | This was maintained in the early Abhidhamma Vibhaṅga (Vb 1), but in the later systematization of the Dhammasaṅgaṇī, the saṅkhārākhandha_ was extended to include all mental factors except feeling, perception, and consciousness (Ds 2.1.1:75.1). As an umbrella category it was then fully defined in the commentarial list of fifty mental factors, of which intention is only one (see Visuddhimagga 14.131). The aim of the Abhidhamma project is to be fully inclusive and systematic, but the role of this aggregate in the Suttas is not to be inclusive, but rather to highlight the significance of intention, will, or volition in creating and maintaining our sense of self.

sn22.56:10.2.eng: There are these six classes of intention:

sn22.56:10.3.pli: rūpasañcetanā, saddasañcetanā, gandhasañcetanā, rasasañcetanā, phoṭṭhabbasañcetanā, dhammasañcetanā.
sn22.56:10.3.eng: intention regarding sights, sounds, smells, tastes, touches, and ideas.

sn22.56:10.7.pli: Ayameva ariyo aṭṭhaṅgiko maggo saṅkhāranirodhagāminī paṭipadā, seyyathidaṃ—
sn22.56:10.7.eng: The practice that leads to the cessation of choices is simply this noble eightfold path …

sn22.56:11.1.pli: Ye hi keci, bhikkhave, samaṇā vā brāhmaṇā vā evaṃ saṅkhāre abhiññāya, evaṃ saṅkhārasamudayaṃ abhiññāya, evaṃ saṅkhāranirodhaṃ abhiññāya, evaṃ saṅkhāranirodhagāminiṃ paṭipadaṃ abhiññāya saṅkhārānaṃ nibbidāya virāgāya nirodhāya paṭipannā, te suppaṭipannā.

sn22.56:11.2.pli: Ye suppaṭipannā, te imasmiṃ dhammavinaye gādhanti.

sn22.56:12.1.pli: Ye ca kho keci, bhikkhave, samaṇā vā brāhmaṇā vā evaṃ saṅkhāre abhiññāya, evaṃ saṅkhārasamudayaṃ abhiññāya, evaṃ saṅkhāranirodhaṃ abhiññāya, evaṃ saṅkhāranirodhagāminiṃ paṭipadaṃ abhiññāya saṅkhārānaṃ nibbidā virāgā nirodhā anupādā vimuttā, te suvimuttā.

sn22.56:12.3.pli: Ye kevalino vaṭṭaṃ tesaṃ natthi paññāpanāya.

sn22.56:13.2.eng: There are these six classes of consciousness:

sn22.56:13.3.pli: cakkhuviññāṇaṃ, sotaviññāṇaṃ, ghānaviññāṇaṃ, jivhāviññāṇaṃ, kāyaviññāṇaṃ, manoviññāṇaṃ.
sn22.56:13.3.eng: eye, ear, nose, tongue, body, and mind consciousness.

sn22.56:13.5.eng: Consciousness originates from name and form.

sn22.56:13.6.eng: When name and form cease, consciousness ceases.

sn22.56:13.7.pli: Ayameva ariyo aṭṭhaṅgiko maggo viññāṇanirodhagāminī paṭipadā, seyyathidaṃ—
sn22.56:13.7.eng: The practice that leads to the cessation of consciousness is simply this noble eightfold path, that is:

sn22.56:13.8.eng: right view, right thought, right speech, right action, right livelihood, right effort, right mindfulness, and right immersion.

sn22.56:14.1.pli: Ye hi keci, bhikkhave, samaṇā vā brāhmaṇā vā evaṃ viññāṇaṃ abhiññāya, evaṃ viññāṇasamudayaṃ abhiññāya, evaṃ viññāṇanirodhaṃ abhiññāya, evaṃ viññāṇanirodhagāminiṃ paṭipadaṃ abhiññāya viññāṇassa nibbidāya virāgāya nirodhāya paṭipannā, te suppaṭipannā.
sn22.56:14.1.eng: Whatever ascetics and brahmins have directly known consciousness in this way—and its origin, its cessation, and the practice that leads to its cessation—and are practicing for disillusionment, dispassion, and cessation regarding consciousness: they are practicing well.

sn22.56:14.2.pli: Ye suppaṭipannā, te imasmiṃ dhammavinaye gādhanti.
sn22.56:14.2.eng: Those who practice well have a footing in this teaching and training.

sn22.56:15.1.pli: Ye ca kho keci, bhikkhave, samaṇā vā brāhmaṇā vā evaṃ viññāṇaṃ abhiññāya, evaṃ viññāṇasamudayaṃ abhiññāya, evaṃ viññāṇanirodhaṃ abhiññāya, evaṃ viññāṇanirodhagāminiṃ paṭipadaṃ abhiññāya viññāṇassa nibbidā virāgā nirodhā anupādā vimuttā, te suvimuttā.
sn22.56:15.1.eng: Those ascetics and brahmins who have directly known consciousness in this way—and its origin, its cessation, and the practice that leads to its cessation—and due to disillusionment, dispassion, and cessation regarding consciousness, are freed by not grasping: they are well freed.

sn22.56:15.2.eng: Those who are well freed are consummate ones.

sn22.56:15.3.pli: Ye kevalino vaṭṭaṃ tesaṃ natthi paññāpanāyā”ti.
sn22.56:15.3.eng: For consummate ones, there is no cycle of rebirths to be found.”
